awd_titl_txt: BD Spokes: SPOKE: NORTHEAST: Collaborative Research: Integration of Environmental Factors and Causal Reasoning Approaches for Large-Scale Observational Health Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Vast quantities of health, environmental, and behavioral data are being generated today, yet they remain locked in digital silos. For example, data from health care providers, such as hospitals, provide a dynamic view of health of individuals and populations from birth to death. At the same time, government institutions and industry have released troves of economic, environmental, and behavioral datasets, such as indicators of income/poverty, adverse exposure (e.g., air pollution), and ecological factors (e.g., climate) to the public domain. How are economic, environmental, and behavioral factors linked with health? This project will put together numerous sources of large environmental and clinical data streams to enable the scientific community to address this question. By breaking current data silos, the broader scientific impacts will be wide. First, this effort will foster new routes of biomedical investigation for the big data community. Second, the project will enable discoveries that will have behavioral, economic, environmental, and public health relevance.

This project will aim to assemble a first-ever data warehouse containing numerous health/clinical, environmental, behavioral, and economic data streams to ultimately enable causal discovery between these data sources. First, the team will integrate numerous health data streams by leveraging the Observational Health Data Sciences and Informatics (OHDSI, www.ohdsi.org) network, a virtual data repository that contains millions of longitudinal patient measurements, such as drugs and disease diagnoses. Second, the team will build a centralized data warehouse that contains important environmental, behavioral, and economic data across the United States, such as the Environmental Protection Agency air pollution AirData, the United States Census data on income and occupation statistics, and the National Oceanic Administration Association for climate and weather-related information. Third, the team will disseminate emerging computational methods for causal inference and machine learning to enable researchers to find causal links between environmental, economic, behavioral, and clinical factors. The team will leverage our broad collaborative network consisting of academic big data researchers, federal-level institutes (e.g., EPA, NOAA), and hospitals (e.g., Partners HealthCare) to integrate these data and to disseminate cutting edge machine learning tools. Lastly, the project will create training resources (e.g., interactive how-to guides), coordinate cross-institution student internships, and lead a hands-on workshop to demonstrate use of the integrated data warehouse. The ultimate goal of the project is to facilitate community-led and collaborative causal discovery through dissemination of integrated and open big data and analytics tools.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The emergence of big data offers unprecedented opportunities for extracting actionable knowledge and insights and advancing scientific discovery across virtually all areas of human endeavor. Healthcare is no exception. However, realizing the promise and potential of big data to improve our understanding of health risks and health outcomes presents several challenges in data integration, artificial intelligence, and related areas.

Vast quantities of health, environmental, and behavioral data are being generated today, yet they remain locked in digital silos. For example, data from health care providers, such as hospitals, provide a dynamic view of health of individuals and populations from birth to death. At the same time, government institutions and industry have released troves of economic, environmental, and behavioral datasets, such as indicators of income/poverty, adverse exposure (e.g., air pollution), and ecological factors (e.g., climate) to the public domain. How are economic, environmental, and behavioral factors linked with health? This project was aimed at integrating numerous sources of large environmental and clinical data streams to enable the scientific community to address such questions; and enabling discoveries that will have behavioral, economic, environmental, and public health relevance.

The project leveraged additional institutional resources to develop Digital Collaboratory for Precision Health Research (DCPHR), infrastructure for secure, and policy compliant analyses of health data. DCPHR leverages the common data model for electronic health records data developed by the Observational Health Data Sciences and Informatics (OHDSI, www.ohdsi.org)  consortium to assemble a deidentified data set consisting of hundreds of thousands of patients of Penn State Health. The resulting  longitudinal data set of electronic health records offers unprecedented opportunities for data-driven discovery of actionable insights from health data to understand health risks and health outcomes. In collaboration with collaborators from Harvard University, the project assembled ExposomeDB, a geo-indexed repository of environmental data (collected by the Environmental Protection Agency), socio-demographic data (collected by the United States Census Bureau), and weather and climate data from the National Oceanic Administration. The resulting multimodal data can be linked to deidentified, but geo-indexed individual electronic health data to understand the complex interactions between clinical, socio-demographic, and other factors that impact health risks and health outcomes, drive health disparities, etc. to inform individual as well as population health interventions for improving health outcomes.

The project developed sophisticated new statistical machine learning and causal inference methods for predictive and causal modeling from relational and  high dimenstional longitudinal data across a broad range of applications. The resulting methods are already being applied to understand the clinical, socio-demographic and other factors that individually and collectively drive health risks and impact health outcomes. 

The project provided enhanced research-based training opportunities for graduate students in Computer Science, Informatics, Data Sciences, Artificial Intelligence and related areas at Pennsylvania State University. Some of the research results are being incorporated into graduate and undergraduate curricula in Data Sciences and Informatics at the university. The establishment of DCPHR has significantly lowered the barriers to collaboration between clinical and biomedical researchers and scientists with expertise in machine learning, causal inference, and related areas of data Sciences at Pennsylvania State University. Free dissemination of research results, publications, open-source implementations of advanced machine learning and causal inference algorithms, as well as educational resources will increase the broader impacts of the research project. 


Last Modified: 03/29/2022
Modified by: Vasant G Honavar
